sn22.100:2.1: Said by the commentary to be a large painting taken from place to place by certain brahmin heretics in their “wanderings” and exhibited to illustrate kamma and its results. This suggests the sense of “conduct” (caraṇa), although the commentary does not make this connection. Perhaps, too, there is a pun on the idea of “wandering mind”. | The commentary says the brahmins were of the Sāṁkhya school, but this is anachronistic as that school arose much later.
sn22.100:2.3: The text plays on three meanings of citta: “mind”, “painting”, and “diversity”, as well as the past participle cittita, “thought up”, “devised”.
